body: If no Android virtual device is running, you have to start it from the Android AVD Manager. Would be good to have en entry in tools to open that, similar to what Android Studio has (we should probably call it `Android AVD Manager`):

comment_data.body: Upon closer look, looks like the AVD Manager is an Android Studio dialog, so would we have to recreate that also?
There's probably a way to interact with the command-line tool. We may not (easily) get device creation, but we should be able to launch them.
OK. Launching is definitely the most important part.

Looks like the following might work?

```
> $ANDROID_HOME\tools\emulator -list_avds
Nexus_5X

> $ANDROID_HOME\tools\emulator -avd Nexus_5X
```
That worked for me locally (`$ANDROID_HOME/tools/emulator -list-avds`). Seems like a good addition, and a nice parallel to the iOS support.
(just fyi, I ran into a case yesterday where I could have used this)

I'm thinking we'll depend on `$ANDROID_HOME` being set. In case it's not... should we simply tell them that? I'm assuming we don't want to support path setting. For instance like: I guess another approach would be configuring an external tool? (On second thought I don't think this is quite right.) @devoncarew

Yeah, don't know. We should, in as much as is possible, use the android sdk that flutter_tools will use. Flutter tools locates that three different ways; using `ANDROID_HOME`, using `PATH`, and using the value the user might have set in `flutter config  --android-studio-dir`. We don't really want to replicate this logic in intellij.

We may want to add some way for the flutter tool to communicate basic settings back to a caller. `flutter doctor --json`? `flutter config --dump-settings`?
Re-titeling to make a little less implementation specific.
This came up with several participants in the recent developer event. They thought their installation was "broken" as the Device Selected had an iOS entry but no Android entry.

+1 to this ticket -- I have a Flutter project and I'd love to use AVD Manager right there within the project. For some reason, when I open up a flutter project, the Android menu no longer appears in the Tools menu, which means I can't run AVD manager easily from within the project as a work-around either.
@mit-mit : Really just prioritization.  Ideally this should happen in the flutter tools layer.  Alternatively we can shim it into the plugin.

As a partial step, let's:

- list existing emulator devices
- offer to open emulators
i started android emulator from android studio but intellij still doesn't load any devices.

rename.from: Add an entry to Tools > Flutter to open the Android AVD Manager
rename.to: Add an entry to Tools for opening the Android AVD Manager

rename.from: Add an entry to Tools for opening the Android AVD Manager
rename.to: Enable starting an Android simulator from IntelliJ like we do for iOS

title: Enable starting an Android simulator from IntelliJ
